name: 1-dodecanol
Reason: 1-dodecanol has a melting point of 10.5°C. The basic unit for our comparison will be dodecane, which has a melting point of -10.0°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The structural modifications we need to consider are the presence of two additional methyl groups. Methyl groups, when connected to a dodecanol base, tend to increase the melting point due to the enhancement of the crystalline structure and the increase in molecular weight. In the case of 1-dodecanol, we have two additional methyl groups linked in a linear fashion, which would notably augment the melting point. Each additional methyl group can be estimated to add approximately 10°C to the melting point due to increased molecular weight and rigidity.
